description.text:
Hello! This is the update design of the Stead i Cam. We've fixed a few issues, here is a list with all the improvements:
  • smaller laser foot print (600mm x 300mm)
  • updated camera-plate (even if your glue breaks, your camera will still stay on the frame
  • we've converted everything to M4
  • completely new bearing holder, requires almost no glue, the bearing sits inside a cage, doesn't slip through the handle like some previous versions, sits on top of the handle
  • the axle goes all the way through the handle for increased robustness
  • the train (the thing inside the frame that moves forward/backwards) is updated, too many improvements to mention
  • added a bill of materials!
    • The original design can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14226 The Stead i Cam is designed by Frits Stam en Koen de Greef. This project originated from the urge to create tools that help designers create professional results in times of budget cuts. With â€˜Tools for Designâ€™ we aim to create a community that helps in the development of instruments used in the design process. The Stead-I-Cam is an example of one of these tools. It supports smooth and professional moving video footage. It is created from a single sheet of laser-cut material, making it easy for any student to create and assemble. This open-source project cuts costs for such a professional tool and makes it accessible for every student / diy'er. We love to see your own Stead i Cam so upload a picture of it!

We made an instruction video for assembling the Stead i Cam: http://player.vimeo.com/video/44562408 Bill of materials:
-Cardan koppeling 1 piece, metal 4mm: http://www.ebay.nl/itm/lIl-CNC-Wellenkupplung-Kardan-voll-Metal-4mm-4mm-Welle-/180539097044?pt=RC_Modellbau&hash=item2a08f7ffd4#ht_2935wt_1080
-Bicycle handle (nice colors): http://www.ebay.nl/itm/LOCK-ON-ANODISED-COLOURED-END-HANDLE-GRIPS-FOR-BIKES-AND-SCOOTERS-FREE-POSTAGE-/360410387679?pt=UK_sportsleisure_cycling_bikeparts_SR&var=&hash=item92b05ef96c#ht_807wt_1313
-Bearings 2 pieces 624-ZZ (4mmx13mmx5mm): http://www.ebay.nl/itm/10-Rillenkugellager-Kugellager-624-ZZ-4-13-5-mm-/150373062913?pt=WÃ¤lz_Kugel_Rollenlager&hash=item2302eed901#ht_1529wt_1341
  • M4 thread 165mm , 55mm and 110mm
  • Camera bolt 1/4" x 3/4 HEX: http://www.ebay.nl/itm/1-4-X-3-4-CEI-BOLT-26TPI-PACK-TEN-/260917305958?pt=UK_Motorcycle_Parts&hash=item3cbfe22266#ht_500wt_1092
  • a few nylon and regular M4 nuts
  • M4 washers for weight

title: LED insert for Kijai's Forbidden Watchtower

description.text:
This is an LED insert for kijai's excellent Forbidden Watchtower model.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2574499

I got the idea from yougurt's make of the tower, however that make was scaled up to fit the Tinkercard LED GLOW Circuit. https://www.thingiverse.com/make:392772

I didn't want to reprint and/or scale the model so I made a version of the glow circuit insert that fits inside the roof cap for the original model.

To install, I removed some of the support material inside the roof cap, but left a few layers to have a flat surface. Then simply glued it to the roof cap. If someone is more ambitious they could combine this model with the roof cap and print it that way. I went the easy route since I had already printed the full Forbidden Tower model.

Needed:

  • LED
  • 2032 coin battery

This is a quick and dirty design. Non functional of course.
I have included the contacts, blades and pivots as reference, but I will be making mine out of 1/4 wood, and I'll be turning the handle on a wood lathe.

The handle can house a #6 32 rod or bolt if desired.

The Base is huge for a 3D priinter. I will be laser cutting mine.

I modeled the plate into two parts to make it easier to print. It now has a provision for a strong magnet and the Handle has a provision for a Screw. together they can hold the switch in the closed position if you want to add movement to the switch.

description.text: I designed this lightsaber body for the PVC lightsaber I am making for my son. The dimensions of the piece are the same as 1" schedule 40 electrical PVC pipe. 1 - 1/4" schedule 40 PVC pipe fits perfectly over it and can joined easily to make a very nice lighsaber body that can be combined with electronics to make a very high quality saber with light and sound. I would recommend just cutting regular PVC pipe for this part of the saber. I only modeled it to see how pieces would look together with it.

description.text:
This is a basic box I made as one of my first Fusion 360 projects.
It works as simple as removing two screws from left Y-axis motor and screwing them back on with box installed between the screws and the acrilic plate.
To get a right-hand box you can just mirror it so that the holes are in the right place.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2-0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Best print position is with bottom of the box as the bottom of the print.

You NEED support for the part where the plate you screw the box with anet's frame is. Otherwise it won't print well. It doesn't have to be high density, just enough so your printer won't have problems with overhangs which are quite long in this model.

Resolution really doesn't matter, the box is rounded in few places but it doesn't make any structural difference if you go with lower resolution.

Post print

Remove support which should be behind the box and under the screw-in plate.

title: Prusa MMU Parts for 3030 Extrusion Frame

description.text:
An assortment of brackets to enable you to fit the Prusa MMU Kit to the frame of a Haribo or similar printer using 3030 extrusion profile.

Motor Mounts
The brackets are a click fit to the frame and don't even need a T-Nut and bolt to affix but of course it is always advisable to use those just to be sure.

The downloadable file contains both brackets. Once fitted to the frame just bolt the motor mounts in the exact same way as per the Prusa instructions for the MMU kit in Part 3, Steps 12 and 13.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9nYrRDo15b0

Electronics Box (old version)
A bracket that enables you to mount the larger style electronics assembly box to the frame above the Rambo box. The 2 larger holes fit over the existing corner frame bolt heads and the lower hole needs an additional T-nut and M6 bolt to secure.

Rambo Mount Bracket
This bracket allows you to mount your original Rambo case to the 3030 frame. You will need to slightly trim the corners of the door hinge pieces slightly to avoid the 3030 fixing bolt heads but this will in no way affect the door.

PSU Bracket
This part allows you to use the existing lower PSU cover by simply drilling the rear hole out to 6,mm then use this bracket to fix the upper part of the PSU case to the frame. It uses a T-Nut and M6 bolt to attach to the 3030 frame and you will need a slightly longer screw/bolt to affix the upper part of the case.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

40% + recommended for strength

description.text: This is my harddisc out of my old laptop, now I use it as a backup hard disc so I needed a case. Since I own a laser cutter I made a case for it. It's made from 2mm acrylic.

  • Attach the side parts with holes to the hard disc with m3 screws.

  • Wait until the glue is dry, then you can, if you want to, change the screws from the side to the bottom. (watch out for scratched from the screws!)
  • If engraved, use a dry/whiteboard marker and fill the engravings, then wipe it of with a tissue.
  • Enjoy your own made hard disc case!

title: Duet3d filament monitor mount for E3D titan

description.text:
PLEASE NOTE:
This thing is a work in progress - it is currently based entirely on theory and maths! I have yet to get hold of a sensor to verify that any of this actually works... OpenSCAD files will follow soon, once I've tidied them up a bit.

This is a mount to attach a Duet3d filament sensor (https://duet3d.com/wiki/Duet3d_Filament_Monitor) to an E3D Titan (https://e3d-online.com/titan-extruder) when used in a bowden setup. It replaces the aluminium bowden adaptor and places the sensor in-line with the output of the extruder. There is a hole at the base of the assembly where an E3D press-in pneumatic fitting is intended to go, to lock the bowden tube in place.

This differs from a lot of other designs in that rather than using a bearing to provide pressure against the hobbed insert, the bowden tube is instead notched using an 8mm drill bit (jig plans to come soon...) and pressure is provided against it using a "spring" printed from the flexible filament of your choice, adjusting the infil to suit the material in question. This provides the filament with as little chance of escape as possible (crucial with flexibles!).

Parts you'll need: (apart from the sensor and printed parts...)
2x 623ZZ Bearing
1x hobbed insert
1x 16mm M3 hex bolt
1x magnet
4x countersunk 10mm M3 bolt

First, insert the "spring" into its cavity. Then, assemble the bearings and hobbed insert as detailed on the Duet3d wiki page (https://duet3d.com/wiki/Duet3d_Filament_Monitor). This is then inserted into the housing from the front, magnet first. Once insterted all the way, the bottom bearing will sit up against the flange in the hole and the magnet should be flush with the base. The PCB is then screwed to the 4 small standoffs with the sensor IC under the magnet. The PCB is not enclosed to permit access to the connectors and to allow a clear view of the LEDs. Finally, the notched PTFE tube is slid in and the whole assembly is then fitted to the Titan.

title: 19th Century Telegraph Key / Manipulateur télégraphique du 19ième siècle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
(Le français suit l'anglais)

Early forms of long-distance communication were based primarily on sending codes and symbols using visual indicators. Examples of this include smoke signals and semaphore towers. The discovery of electricity made it possible to transmit messages along electrical lines. This spurred considerable research, culminating in the invention of the electric telegraph. The electric telegraph was more versatile and reliable than visual indicators. It also provided instantaneous contact, revolutionizing long-distance communications.

A telegraph key is used to transmit messages in an electrical telegraph. Telegraph keys come in many different models. The one seen here can be found in Ingenium’s collection of artifacts and is called a Camelback because of the hump-shaped look of the lever. It is made out of brass and was used in a telegraph office in Metcalfe, Ontario, which opened in 1870 and closed in 1912.

Note: The complete scan of the artifact is named "Telegraph key.stl". It is meant to be viewed in a virtual environment using computer software. You can try printing it off, though we cannot guarantee the quality. To construct your own telegraph key please download the "Telegraph - parts.zip" file and visit the website
https://ingeniumcanada.org/ingenium/museums/education/3D-telegraph-key.php

Our terms of use can be found at: https://ingeniumcanada.org/ingenium/doc/content/cstmc/CSTMC%20terms%20of%20use%203D%20ENG.pdf

Les premières communications sur de longues distances consistaient essentiellement à transmettre des codes et des symboles au moyen d’indicateurs visuels, comme des signaux de fumée. L’avènement de l’électricité a permis la transmission de messages le long de lignes électriques. Il en est découlé de nombreux travaux de recherche, qui ont culminé avec l’invention du télégraphe électrique, moyen plus fiable que les signaux visuels. En outre, le télégraphe électrique procurait un contact instantané, ce qui a révolutionné les communications sur de longues distances.

Le manipulateur télégraphique est la partie d’un télégraphe électrique qui sert à transmettre les messages. Il en existe de nombreux modèles. Celui que vous voyez ici fait partie de la collection d’artefacts d’Ingenium. Il est dit « à dos de chameau » en raison de l’aspect du levier. Il est fait de laiton et a été utilisé dans un bureau télégraphique de Metcalfe (Ontario), qui a été ouvert de 1870 à 1912.

Remarque : L’image 3D complète de l’artefact porte le nom « Telegraph key.stl ». Il est conçu pour être visualisé dans un environnement virtuel au moyen d’un logiciel. Vous pouvez tenter de l’imprimer. Toutefois, nous ne pouvons garantir la qualité de l’impression. Pour fabriquer votre propre manipulateur télégraphique, téléchargez le fichier « Telegraph - parts.zip » et visitez le site
https://ingeniumcanada.org/ingenium/musees/educatif/manipulateur-telegraphique-3D.php

Vous trouverez nos conditions d’utilisation à l’adresse https://ingeniumcanada.org/ingenium/doc/content/cstmc/CSTMC%20terms%20of%20use%203D%20FR.pdf

author: pw98

description.text: Doesn't everyone need to design a phone case or phone/tablet stand when they get their shiny new 3d printer? Here's the one I created for my iPad to use at the breakfast table while catching up on the news. In essence, it is a vertical reading stand for tablets and e-readers. The basic design is for the iPad2 &3 without their covers on. Other designs are described in the instructions and can be used with all iPads with/without their covers attached.

Print at 20% fill and use exterior support for versions with the extruded text. I also suggest setting your platform temp to 110C for minimizing curl. I generally do use raft support but your mileage may vary. 
Use eStand_plain.stl if you'd prefer the design without the embossed text. Use eStand_deep.stl if you'd like to use the reader with your iPad cover on. Use eStand_deep_plain.stl for the deeper reader with no embossed text. The deeper channel variants have been tested with all iPads with the standard covers.

This was a miniaturized version of an HVAC blower I designed(actual wheel diameter is 20" in real life).
https://youtu.be/_26Szj1rbzs

I printed all parts with same settings, 0.2mm layer, 20% infill, used brim when having trouble with parts curling off bed(mainly the frames)

I got the motor from Digikey, part# 1597-1210-ND, then designed the motor housing to fit it with a small dip switch. Then used 12V A23 batteries inside to run the motor.

For the bearings I used 7/8" OD with 3/8" ID, can't get them in a lot of places.

Printed a belt using elastomer filament(just a circle the right size).

Then I super glued the parts together.

I mirrored the stl in Cura for both sides of the wheel, scroll housing, and for both frame sides required.

Various Bushing stl files included so you can vary your fan rpm as desired, or you can use a potentiometer to adjust the motor speed(hole in motor cap to mount the pot).

I have been asked recently to contribute some WoW models and have discovered that latest version of WoW model viewer (https://wowmodelviewer.atlassian.net/wiki/display/WMV/Download+WoW+Model+Viewer)
is not exporting models at selected animation key but only the initial pose. From their forums: "Hi, I didn't do any effort yet on exporter and wmo. My first concern was to have a clean base to play with (as if a model is not correctly loaded, it doesn't make sense to try to export it)" Since then I have found the work around: export in FBX format with all the animations, import in 3ds Max (free if you have educational license), find animation key that you like and then export as STL.
I did thicken the wings a bit because they have been modeled as 2-sided polys but it is still an iffy print, i noticed among other things that Kisslicer and Slic3r are not generating support for horns.

Here is my very simple but effective printing test column.

I printed it especially with different Temperatures and different Retraction Speeds!

I got interesting results and learned a lot how some settings are effecting my prints.
I can really recommend this simple test.
It needs about 3-4 min and about 113 mm of filament.

(I recommend to print with skirt and upright)

I hope you have fun with it!!

print_settings.Notes:: Pictured parts are printed with coarse layer settings with a 0.6mm nozzle.

description.text:
I have built a larger 300mm cube Hypercube, and after delaying for a little while I upgraded to four 12mm smooth rods for the z-axis. Other 12mm rod mounts were causing clashing between the bearing mounts and my heated bed, so I redesigned some mounts such that the smooth rods are as close to the frame as I could get. As a bonus I can access a few more centimeters of my build platform that were blocked by the z-axis smooth rods.

I have also included a Z-axis endstop switch mount I created that should be a direct switch out from Tech2C's original, but for 12mm smooth rods.

All hardware for original parts should fit with these to attach to 2020 extrusion. To clamp the smooth rod an M3x20 screw should fit. The nut trap might be a tight fit, but you can heat press the nut in place if it's giving trouble.

Support me on Patreon

To help me deliver quality printable terrain models:

Space ship wreckage

This was just a quick model I made to test how a space whip wreckage could be used as terrain. I haven't put lots of effort in it and I would like to expand this line. Wrecks make great terrain. They can be used for objective markers, scenarios, sources of treasures etc.

It would also be neat to have space ships and their wreckage. That way you can substitute the model for the wreck when the ship is shot down.

Since the shape is very abstract it can be painted very simple and still look ok for a game. Simply spray it black and drybrush some silver. You can also paint it with different grey shades. A brown wash can make it appear dirty. The blasted parts can be painted darker.
This bear was modeled for a class in blender. It has a skeleton inside to be re-positioned.

description.text:
Need a sneaky evil, small cheap geocache to confound the local cachers? Or do you just need a tiny container for keeping really small things in (why would you need that!?)

Then grab a soft drink bottle top, print out this container and screw them together!

Features an inset logo of a rocket, which is actually a finger grab handle to aid unscrewing of the container.

Takes about 20 minutes to print. Ive printed 6 this evening!

UPDATE!!!!
As requested I have added a version of the container with a geocaching logo in the end. Not only that, Ive also included a dimpled version, and the blank, so you can design your own logo. Be warned! - These designs are not as easy to unscrew, as they dont contain the grab handle in the rocket design, they rely more on thumb friction.

title: Vintage Tube Radio Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to create a nightstand lamp that had a AC wall plug and USB plugs for all my charging needs at night. Couldn't find anything to buy that I liked that was affordable so I created this thingi. It is a simple lamp I tried to make look like a an old vintage tube radio. I got some vintage LEDs, outlets, extension cable, candelabra sockets, dimmer switch from a home improvement place. Got the faux "tubes" from a local craft store. Works well and puts off a nice warm glow. I printed in glossy black PLA, which, in hindsight wasn't the best idea. I think this could turn out better in wood PLA with a nice stain job.

EDIT: I have had some requests for BOM list. I have attached a photo of the receipt from my trip to get most of the lamp parts. Everything should be there with the exception of the plastic tube covers. I got those from a craft store. I think these are them: http://www.michaels.com/plastic-test-tube-treat-containers-by-celebrate-it/10411280.html

EDIT: I have added a simple STL for printable shades if you want to diffuse more light than the clear test tubes do. The attached photo shows clear PETG shades at 1mm thickness (two passes with my 0.5 mm nozzle) I also printed some shades in glow in the dark PLA. They looked fantastic but the glowing was too bright!

DISCLAIMER: I am not an electrician! I know some basics for 120v appliance wiring and thats about it. If you want to make and wire up your own lamp, please do this at your own risk.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

I only needed supports on the LampTop.stl file. I wanted to make sure the top part of the outlet bracket looked good. If your printer bridges 40 ish mm well, then you should be fine.

The tolerances are press-fit tight. You will want to do this with a pretty accurate printer with filament that doesn't shrink to get the parts to fit. If you have trouble with fit, i would recommend scaling the light mounts and the outlet bracket just a little, since they are smaller and quicker to reprint.

Print, assemble, and wire-up. Use a soft squishy filament for the feet and wire relief.

comments.text: Do you have a parts list for this? Especially the bulb size and the candelabra base that you used for it.

I got those in a pack of 4 from crafts shop for about $5. They came with little silver lids. I'm not sure what they are called or what isle they were in.

title: Fishing lure #3 with gills and larger body

description.text:
Here is another of my fishing lure designs. This one is larger than my last ones but could be scaled up or down to suit your needs. The pivot allows for a more realistic swimming action when combined with the bill.
This is a diving lure I printed at 100% so it would be a bit heavier but if you change the infill you change the buoyancy. A great side benefit to choosing your settings and making these lures even more custom. I have included the source for you as well.
I paint them to look like local fish. This one I tried to mimic a perch but you could experiment with fluorescent or metallic colours. Different regions have different feeder fish but fish will react out of movement or curiosity.
UPDATE!
They totally work! Check out the action shots! Small mouth bass and pike love yellow perch.
The northern pike took 10 minutes to land, they have some fight in them and it is about 30 inches long. They live for about 25-30 years. I estimate this one to be in it's 20s for sure. The small mouth bass was probably 3.5-4 pounds. There were a lot this year. seems the warmer weather is proving to be beneficial for the fish!
FISH ON!

Scale the STL and print at 100% to survive hard strikes and rocks.
Use the appropriate hardware to your scale.
You will need the following:
-5 screw in eyelets
-2 treble hooks
-2 small split rings
-Some paint or coloured plastic
Paint the body components first then assemble.
Head out and catch that one that keeps getting away!

title: PianoLamp cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My first led light, called "The Arc" was used by my wife it as a piano light. After some time she complained that the cone of light was to shallow to enlighten two pages of music. So I got back to the shop and made another version using leds on a long pcb. To hide the ugly part I milled corresponding holes into pvc hard foam and sandwiched it with a bar of birch plywood. Apart from the head I just had to change the connector to the arm.

My build was done from 6,5 mm birch plywood, 5 mm PVC hard foam and some 4 mm high density fiber using a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft. The 'arm' needs to be cut twice from the high density fiber.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs. Consider a donation if you like the build.

author: ZenziWerken

description.text: Un petit bol pour serpent à placer dans un vivarium ou autre.

This is a little stand I needed to make for a laser spirograph. Finding a place to mount these little motors is always a tricky task, and precision is a must with optics. It's essentially a cube which has some holes for zip ties. I've kept the file very simple, so you can modify the model and customize if for your own needs! Important!!
Motor Dimensions:
20mm width (perpendicular to axle, across round body sections)
25mm body length (parallel to the axle)
15mm body height (where the motor is flattened in two spots) Be sure to take several measurements and confirm everything will line up. The holes are located precisely so that two tight wire ties will securely affix the motor. There is a gap in the bottom so that the block may be stood on a flat surface, and the wire ties will not interfere with adhesion. Final height of the center of the axle is approximately 1.25 inches vertically mounted. Hope it's helpful!

ABS plastic is recommended. It is soft and workable for a wide variety of situations.  
You will need two zip ties, mounting tape, or some other way of attaching the motor to the mount.  
If you use mounting tape, the zip tie holes may be tapped and used as screw holes.

title: Witcher's Silver Sword with Dowel Holes

description.text: I found the wonderful Wticher sword by Lotis, but my printer was not large enough for his pieces. I also wanted it to be a little sturdier than the glue I had would allow. I also included a wall mount design if you want to put it up like I did.

Monoprice Mini Select

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

20

Notes:

The dowel holes are designed for 1/8 and 3/16 dowels, they will be a tight fit, but they will hold strong.

Sand

Make sure the whole thing is smooth before painting or assembling, it will be much easier that way.

Paint

I used one coat of gray primer and then four coats of silver spraypaint for the silver portions.

Changes to the original

The blade is now 9 pieces rather than 5, simply because my printer is too small for the larger pieces. I also added dowel holes to the original, and they run through all the pieces.

remixed_from.author: juliantoledo
remixed_from.title: Sony E-Mount body to Nikon F-Mount Lens adapter

title: Sony E-Mount body to Nikon F-Mount Lens adapter

description.text:
This one is made based on Julian Toledo's lens adapter for using Nikon lenses on Sony NEX or A7, A7R and alike body cameras.

Original one you can find here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:719655

Main changes for my edit are:
1) Corrected both Nikon and Sony side bayonet clearances, so neither lens nor body fit don't get loose. Nikon lens will hold on friction, adapter on the camera body will stay both using friction and body clamp. Original design was a bit loose at Sony side and WAY loose on Nikon's
2) Made some minor changes to the model structure, so it should print using only really necessary supports at the top, where "wings" for the Sony bayonet are. You can print using 5 degrees slope tolerance for the supports. Also, I have removed sharp edges within inner light diffuser, so there will be no stringing during printing process
3) Most of the problem after printing this adapter is to get actual infinity focus using manual lenses. Yeah, it's a pain :) And there is no perfect solution for when you stick lens' focus to infinity and actually to get one. Due to VERY small imperfections in printing process that can result even 150 micron delta between bayonets or just an uneven top surface you won't get a perfect infinity focus. I'll describe it below. So I've made a few editions of the adapter.

Few more things considering adapter thickness for getting infinity focus:
1) AFAIK distance between top (that doesn't count "wings" that goes inside Sony bayonet) must be exactly 28.5 mm. That is how it is in the original design
2) "Safe" thickness is a bit smaller - about 28.3-28.4 mm. This way you can get "overshoot" beyond infinity, but at you'll get infinity focus for sure
3) When printing using ABS it ought to shrink a bit after cooling, making adapter's thickness a bit smaller. It's not very easy to say how much will it go, especially in top to down axis

Now, how you can decide what to print - note that theese models are all the same except for being a bit different in their length:
1) F-E-Adapter_ABS
That's one I've printed with ABS without any additional scaling for printing purposes. I've got really slight overshoot beyond infinity, but generally focus looks really good... Don't ask me why, but it is 0.7 mm shorter than the original design. And yes, the focus is almost perfect. Problem is that I cannot surely confirm infinity focus on other lenses since this Nikon lens is the only one with infinity for the lens itself. So it would be up to you to confirm it or not. But that's not all: I've checked this lens on Fuji S5 Pro camera with native Nikon bayonet and also got slight overshoot. So it is possible this adapter is the optimal one

2) F-E-Adapter_Generic
This is the Julian Toledo's original one with 28.5 tolerance with my changes considering things I've described above. I's just a bit "upgraded" version of the original one.

3) F-E-Adapter_Experimental
I've added 0.1 to the thckness of my ABS version. It looks it could fit perfectly in infinity focus using my printer, but I was lazy to actually print it. Again, please note that I couldn't make some serious testing since I have only one lens.

If either of theese will fit your lens, please leave a comment.

Note that shrinkage won't really make difference on adapter's diameter, author made enough of space for lens to fit anyway. Also, do not forget: if you print one with 0.2 or thicker layer, make it about 0.1 at the 28.2-28.6 height - otherwise it won't be precise enough

If you can't insert lens in the adapter, just cut a bit inner lower edges of the adapter - it's just an "elefant's leg" effect making lower layers to bulge out a bit.

This adapter was tested with Nikon E 28/F2.8 and Helios 81M 53/F2.0 (with broken focusing control) manual lenses. Helios was a bit loose (it has slight difference in construction), but also fit well.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

65% using each 2-nd layer (32.5% actual)

Notes:

Recommendatons for printing:
1) It doesn't require brim, so I don't reccomend using it
2) You need support at the top "wings" only, so configure slicer you use the way it doesn't produce any additional supports
3) It's up to you to decide layer thickness, but I've used 0.125 for the most parts of the adapter with 0.1 for the fixing lens parts (top "wings" and bottom ones at the Nikon side

For the ABS versions my layers where as you can see on the attached picture.

Again: if you print with thick layers (0.2 and above), remember to make layers in about 28.2-28.6 height about 0.1 mm or below or you won't get enough precision.
I've made a bit of acetone postprocessing at the top and all the "wings" sections. Though it s not shown on the photos.

author: Harh

title: Modular 28mm Scifi Building Components
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Summary

I'm looking to make some buildings for Infinity to replace the cardboard ones that come in the starter sets. I knew I wanted things that had interesting geometry (read: not just rectangles copy/pasted everywhere) that also had windows, doors, and support for multiple floors with ladders/catwalks/cover on the rooftop.

I also knew that I needed these buildings to be somewhat modular because my mini printer can't print anything above 4.5" in any dimension. These buildings are all built to scale for 28mm miniatures (on the 25.4mm tile scale). I chose not to use OpenLock or any of the existing sets because they seem more suited for dungeon crawlers than wargames.

Please give these a whirl and let me know if you have any issues! My printer is slow and I'm still new to the hobby so I'm learning things as I go, and the more people I have pitching in the faster we can get these standardized and focus on making more/beautiful decorations on them! I need help getting some prints done and finding any issues before I proceed much further.

How to Use

Simply print the floors and walls that you want to use and the pegs needed to put them together. I'm still dealing with print tolerance issues, but you don't really need all 3 pegs on every edge from my experience. You may choose to skip the floor if you don't care about it, or don't care about having a ceiling.

A basic building (like the one shown) uses a series of wall segments and floors for the main level. The second level uses the same pegs to lock into the walls below it. The half walls act as a border to make the ceiling playable. There are ladders and catwalks if you're interested.

Shouldn't need any glue, mix and match and put things together to see how they turn out! I mostly designed these to print with one surface undecorated (interior) so that they wouldn't need supports. You may want supports for the corner pieces, which are too small to have holes on every side.

Known Issues

  • I'm dealing with some peeling issues so I have a number of test pieces that printed where the interior of the wall (printed on the bed) peeled up. This is limited to my printer, but it means that some of my tested pieces don't square up 100% properly.
  • I'm still figuring out the right print tolerances for the pegs (4.95mm at present) and the holes (5.0mm at present). Part of this is due to "sagging" in the holes (again, likely my printer issues) and I'm open to advice on what margins to leave here.

Update Log

*2017/10/12: First post

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.175

Infill:

20%
